content.description: One of the best routes at the crag.Stick clip, and get ready to dance. This party starts with bouldery moves and technical footwork, with the sequence ending in one of the few pockets on the whole wall.  Catch your breath, and traverse to the left Eye of Joe's Nose for a full rest.  Traverse back out and through some 5.11 climbing to the chains.
content.location: Just left of Joe's Nose.

content.description: Start below a shallow hanging corner.  The rock directly below and left of the corner is black choss that will never clean up, but looks inviting.Instead stay more to the right, and boulder through a sequence that is likely to have you reaching wide left, (the FA, short in stature, went full iron-cross here) getting into the corner and laybacking up to a rest.The second half of the route is pretty enjoyable mid 5.11, and can be linked into from the bottom of Chalk Lettuce.
content.location: 2 routes left of the Scorpion Ledge.  The hanging, right facing corner is the best landmark.

content.description: Listing this route as a warning to climbers as it is not in the new guide book. Either this route is unfinished or it was not cleaned properly. There are several loose blocks in the last 20 feet that would do some serious damage to those below if pulled off.The route was fun and mostly clean up until the last bolt visible from the ground. After that there is some wandering runout on easier loose choss creating bad rope drag up to an anchor. Pulling your rope from this anchor will leave your rope in a big prickly pear. IMO this route would be much better if the anchor was at that last visible bolt. I can only assume this route just isn't finished yet but there was no red tag.
content.location: Immediately right of Pocket pancake

content.description: The Stinger climbs the back of Scorpion Ledge in a pretty stemming corner.  Climb sustained 5.10 moves to the top of the corner (one of the higher bolts seems far left, and was easier to clip at waist height).At the top of the corner, clip the last bolt, and perform a bit of a bouldery sequence to get outside to the left, all while the chains are staring you in the face....only 20 inches away.
content.location: The back of the Scorpion Ledge. This route can have a different Sun/Shade aspect than others, and could be a good or bad choice depending on your needs. (ie: Don't climb this if you're cold and it's shady.)

content.description: A silly route. Climb onto a ledge, then up the chimney in the back of.the ledge. Squeeze through the sharp narrow exit.There is a more exciting finish, skipping the squeeze to step right to a single bolt on the exposed face, and onto the ledge.  Airy.
content.location: On the level below the rest of the routes, on the far left side. Start right of a dead tree.

content.description: This route is a lot of fun, interesting climbing throughout with a bit of a stumper crux at the 2nd to last bolt.  Climbs the slightly overhanging rock with interesting cruxy sequences followed by good rests pretty much the whole way up.  At the top, the anchors are up and right from the last bolt on a ledge.
content.protection: 9 bolts to 2 chain anchor with steel lowering biners.
content.location: This is in the middle of the cliff between Gluteal Glochids on the left and Cactus Cowboy on the right.  This is the second route to the right of spineless, the short, chossy 5.8 that goes up the spine of brown rock in the center of the wall.

content.description: This 4 bolt quickie packs a lot of utility, either as a warm up or the bottom of 3 other options.Climb left of the bolts for 2 bolts, then right of the bolts to the top. Easier the second time!Lower off the back of the ledge, or continue up and left to Chalk Lettuce (11a), center to Twenty Inch Stinger (11b) or right Drought Reistant (10b).
content.location: Left-center of the wall, 4 bolts to a ledge.

content.description: Interesting little route that packs a bit of a punch for the grade down low, then eases up in difficulty quite a bit for the top 2/3 of the route.  The route starts up a slab with some interesting thin and balancy moves right around the 2nd bolt where the crux is encountered.  After gaining the good holds right of the second bolt it's an easy jaunt up the good corner crack system above.  The first two bolts have chain permadraws on them, though I'm not quite sure why.
content.protection: 7 bolts to 2 chain anchor, first 2 bolts have chain permadraws on them.
content.location: Center of the wall, just left of the Pocket Pancake Slab.

content.description: This is a short route the climbs some of the worst looking rock on the wall.  It is steeper than it looks from the ground and is almost vertical as it climbs past three bolts before rounding out onto a chossy low angled slab and heading way left to the anchors on the top of scorpion ledge.  Really not worth climbing, but it might be a good way to access the scorpion ledge if you are just looking to do one of the upper portions of the routes starting on the ledge.
content.protection: 3 bolts to two bolt anchor way left of the top of the route.  Anchors have a biner and an open clevis for lowering off of.
content.location: This is the short route that climbs the chossy looking right side of an obvious brown ridge of rock in the left/central portion of the wall.

content.description: This is a fun techy slab route with a very distinct crux right before the last bolt.  Head up easy slab on good holds until you clip the second to last bolt and wonder where all of the holds went.  Find some itty bitty micro crimps and do a couple of hard moves to gain the last bolt where the climbing again eases up to the chains.  Short crux, but it is entertaining none the less.
content.location: Obvious slab route that looks a bit spacey between the 3rd and 4th bolts from the ground (don't worry, the climbing in that section is easy).  The route is located at about the center of the wall, though there are many more routes to the left of this one than to the right.

content.description: Two very closely spaced bolts protect the cruxy starting roof. Easier climbing on sharp, suspect chert leads past two more bolts to the anchors
content.location: On the wall left of Double Barrel Cactus, straight through the biggest part of the low roof.

content.description: At the right end if the cliff are two massive huecos that look like eyes. Joe's Nose climbs the space between them.Sequence your way up to a bulge. Pull over it (crux) and head to the left "eye" for a full rest. 2 more bolts above the eye set you up for some very interesting rock, and a runout on easier climbing to the chains.
content.location: Far right side of the crag. The two "eyes" are hard to miss.

content.description: A great route that gets one letter grade easier every time you repeat it.Climb through a few bolts of easy 5.8 onto a ledge.  Clip the bolt overhead, and head up the steep face, mostly using high feet and layback type moves in the right corner.(The route name refers to an unfortunate encounter the FA had with a cactus on the day she snagged the first ascent.)
content.location: Right of the Scorpion Ledge and Spineless is a dirty chimney and a small cave with a flat landing in front of it. Gluteal Glochids starts just right of the landing.

content.description: Climb onto the Scorpion Ledge, clip a chain draw on the right, and head up some very featured rock.  Long and pretty mellow besides a moment or two.
content.location: Drought Resistant starts on the right side of Scorpion Ledge, and can be approached by Stone Scorpion or Spineless.

content.description: While most chert runs horizontally,  this buttress fell over at some point leaving  the unique vertical stripes.Climb up the narrow pillar of rock. Contrived, as one could just step left onto 4th class terrain.
content.location: Left side of the crag. Thin buttress with vertical chert.

content.description: Classic face climbing bottom to top, this route is a fairly sustained piece of rock with the crux only being a bit harder than any other move.  Some may get flummoxed on the first 2 bolts, but use of a stick clip and some perseverance will get you to all the pleasant climbing above.
content.protection: 9 bolts to lower offs. Stick clip
content.location: Just right of the boulder below Cholla Chuffers.

content.description: A silly route. Do some face climbing to establish under a bulge. Stem, lay back, and meathook up into the crack. Do a jam or two, then crimp up the face left of the crack to anchors atop the ledge.Fancy crack gloves optional. Try not to bleed everywhere.
content.location: Far left side of the crag, one level lower than the rest of the routes. Anchors accessible from the trail.  Left of Tweezer Squeezer.

content.description: Long and fun. This route starts left of a huge flake/boulder on the ground. Head up the crack, eventually moving right to some fancy face moves, and ending with some steep jug hauling near the top.
content.protection: A lot of bolts.  Maybe 14? Lower off.
content.location: This route starts between some cactus and boulder.

content.description: This link-up is a long line of large holds, and skips the thin crux of Chalk Lettuce. A great route for anyone, and a skin-saving warmup for the harder routes. Climb the first 4 bolts of Stone Scorpion, possibly using a longer draw on the 4th bolt. Step to the left side of the ledge and climb the wild arete above. I would also recommend doing the Side Salad Slab above, at least once.
content.location: The ledge and arete left of it.

content.description: Left of the Scorpion Ledge is a deep scoop. Climb up the scoop, pull through the bulge (crux), and cop a rest below the arete.  The arete is an exposed ladder of buckets, and very fun.  One final crimpy section guards the chains. Extension: Pull over the bulge above the anchor, and climb the slab above.  It's only 5.10, but very thoughtful and worthwhile. 70m required to lower.
content.location: Just left of the obvious Scorpion Ledge.

content.description: A striking line through the roofs.  The surprise is the roof is much easier than the top, which is thin, sharp, and cryptic.  This route would be a proud onsight.
content.protection: Permadraws, plus 2 draws for the top.
content.location: Mid cliff. Look for permadraws through the roof.

content.description: The most fun I've had falling off a route. Climb up the slab, to huecos, to the right facing corner.  Every bolt you clip seems to add a grade and a few more degrees of overhang.Climb the corner, clip the permadraw, and work through the gymnastic crux, likely moving left to right, maybe a lay back, maybe stemming, and maybe meat hooking the top of the feature the permadraw is on. A final finger bucket/crimp ladder provides the red point crux, and potential for big air.  Bon voyage.
content.location: Center of the cliff. 1 permadraw. A narrow rib of rock separates Cactus Sale Today on the right and Cactus Cowboy on the left.

content.description: Very classic, sustained, and funClimb up the white streak, move left-to-right under the steepness, and pull up into the corner groove.  If you nail the sequence it will be all big holds the whole way up, with maybe a fingerlock or even an armbar thrown in for good measure.  There's a few places to shake out, and a few places you can't.  It's real climbing right to the end.
content.location: Mid cliff. A pillar of rock high on the wall forms corners on both sides of it.  Cactus Cowboy is on the left of the pillar, while Cactus Sale Today (with the permadraw) is on the right.

content.description: A tricky start that steps left and up into the roof and left facing corner above may warrant stick clipping the second bolt above the roof. Once clear of the corner the climb pulls you slightly left to the fourth bolt before you angle back right into a more broken left facing corner that leads to chain anchors.
content.location: ~25' right of Double Barrel Cactus on the same wall as it.

content.description: While technically not on Mt. Potosi itself, since this cliff is directly across the street from the turnoff for Mt. Potosi Canyon and the Mt. Potosi canyon crags right there, it makes sense to include it a sub-area of Mt. Potosi.  Cactus Joes is a south facing cliff that gets all day sun and has a nice range of grades from 5.8 to hard 5.12.  There aren't a ton of routes, and it's certainly not a destination crag, but it is a fun little area to check out for a day or two if you are looking for warmth and sun or if the sandstone at red rock is wet.
